history.overview: The history of the region that now constitutes Parvathipuram Manyam district can be divided into three main periods: the ancient/medieval era, the colonial era, and the modern administrative formation.

key_points: Part of Ancient Kalinga: The region was once part of the mighty Kalinga Empire along the eastern coast.
Eastern Ganga Dynasty Influence: Temples like Kamalingeswara Swamy Temple in Gallavilli were built during the 11th century CE under King Rajaraja Deva.
Northern Circars: The area belonged to the Northern Circars, controlled by multiple dynasties before coming under the Nizams and the British.
Princely States: The plains region was under the Vizianagaram princely state and local feudal lords.
Agency Tract (Manyam): The British classified the forested hills as Agency Tracts governed by oppressive forest laws like the Madras Forest Act of 1882.
Administrative Hub: Parvathipuram became a sub-divisional administrative center and panchayat board by 1901.
The Manyam Rebellion (1922–1924): Led by Alluri Sitarama Raju, this uprising saw coordinated attacks on British police stations and symbolized tribal resistance against colonial rule.
Post-1947: The Parvathipuram region was initially part of Srikakulam district.
Vizianagaram Formation (1979): Parvathipuram and Salur became part of the newly formed Vizianagaram district.
Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA): Established at Parvathipuram to promote tribal welfare.
District Formation (2022): Created on April 4, 2022, combining parts of Vizianagaram and Srikakulam districts.
District Naming: Initially proposed as 'Manyam district,' later renamed to 'Parvathipuram Manyam district' to honor both heritage and tribal identity.

cultural_highlights.significance: Historical temple dating back to the 15th century.
Originally built in 1908, modern barrage completed in 2015 on the Nagavali River.
Sri Venkateswara Swamy Temple, a major devotional center.
Known for Goddess Paramma Thalli Temple.

colonial_period.title: The Colonial Police as an Instrument of Oppression
details: Under the British rule, the Manyam region was part of the Agency Tracts of the Madras Presidency.
Police enforced restrictive forest laws and suppressed tribal rights.
Corruption and tyranny were rampant, with colonial police exploiting Adivasis.

manyam_rebellion.title: The Manyam Rebellion (1922–1924)
details: Led by Alluri Sitarama Raju, targeting British police stations for weapons.
Famous raids occurred across Agency areas including Chintapalle, Krishnadevi Peta, and Rajavommangi.
British response included Reserve Police, Malabar Special Police, and Assam Rifles deployment.
Martial law imposed; harsh reprisals against tribals followed.
The rebellion ended with Raju’s capture and execution in May 1924.

modern_police.title: Modern Police Administration (Post-2022)
details: District Police Headquarters established at Parvathipuram after formation in 2022.
Includes Police Sub-Divisions headed by SDPOs, Law & Order Stations, CCS, Women’s PS, and Traffic PS.
Focus areas: law and order, community policing, and tribal area coordination.
